summary: A presentation by Jim Cantrell, CEO and Co-Founder of Vector, discussing the new space race, Vector's role, and their innovative strategies in the space industry.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a dark, foggy scene where a bright light beam pierces through the mist, creating an eerie atmosphere. A person wearing a dark jacket and gloves is seen holding a device, possibly a camera or phone, capturing the light beam. The scene transitions to a close-up of a metallic door with a dark, reflective surface, surrounded by a foggy environment, suggesting a mysterious or secretive location. The video then shifts to a brightly lit stage with a large screen displaying the word "VECTOR" in white text on a blue background, indicating a presentation or event. The stage is adorned with purple and blue lights, and the audience is visible in the foreground, suggesting a conference or seminar setting. A man in a dark suit walks onto the stage, addressing the audience with a confident demeanor. The stage is decorated with various logos and text, including "University of Helsinki" and "PwC," indicating the event's sponsors or affiliations. The man continues to speak, gesturing with his hands, while the audience watches attentively. The video concludes with a wide shot of the stage, showing the man standing near a sign that reads "SLUSH," a well-known technology conference, with the audience seated in the foreground, attentively listening to the speaker. The overall atmosphere is professional and engaging, with a focus on the speaker and the event's branding.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with the sound of an electric door opening and closing, creating a mechanical whirring noise. A male speaker then begins addressing an audience, inquiring how many are "space geeks," and describing his unexpected path into the space industry, initially aspiring to race cars but being inspired in college by events like "people going to the moon". He continues, speaking in an energetic and slightly impassioned tone, noting the degradation of the space program and his temporary exit, but hints at a return.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, illuminated by blue and purple lights, addressing an audience in a dimly lit venue. The stage features a large screen displaying the text "HIS" and "IBM," with the audience visible in the background. The scene transitions to a graphic of two rockets launching into the night sky, accompanied by the text "A New Space Race Is Here" and "Next 5 Years, Might New Satellites in Orbit Than Entire Prior 50 Years," highlighting the rapid advancement in satellite technology. The video then returns to the stage, where the man continues his presentation, gesturing with his hands. The stage is adorned with vertical light strips, and the audience remains engaged. The presentation shifts to a slide titled "Micro Satellite Disruption," comparing traditional and micro satellites in terms of launch mass, cost, and development time, with the text "VECTOR" at the bottom. The video concludes with a close-up of the slide, emphasizing the significant differences between traditional and micro satellites, underscoring the technological shift in the space industry.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker announcing "Things have changed" and he is back because things are different. He continues, adopting an excited tone, describing the impact of entrepreneurs and a new generation of people on the space industry. He says "a new space race is here." Describing his company, he says it was formed a couple of years ago to participate in a massive revolution in space. He then explains the "microsatellite disruption," contrasting old satellites with modern ones that are smaller, cheaper, and faster to develop. The speaker concludes by stating that this has drawn in investors and a new generation of people, making the space race a reality.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a comparison between traditional and micro satellites, highlighting their differences in average launch mass, cost, and development time. Traditional satellites have an average launch mass of 1650 kg, cost over 100 million USD, and take 4 years to develop, with 40 satellites launched in 2015 and 60 in 2020. In contrast, micro satellites have an average launch mass of 20 kg, cost between 0.1 to 1 million USD, and take less than a year to develop, with 175 satellites launched in 2015 and 675 in 2020. The scene then transitions to a dark background with the title "Existing Launch Options Dismal." It contrasts the limited capacity of current launch options, which allow for less than 300 satellites per year, with the desired capacity of over 1000 satellites per year. The video emphasizes the disparity between the current limitations and the potential of dedicated launches, using images of satellite launch vehicles to illustrate the point. The atmosphere is informative and focused on the technological and economic aspects of satellite launches.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features one male speaker discussing the challenges of launching satellites into orbit. He describes the current options as "dismal," explaining that micro satellites are often launched on larger rockets with other satellites, likening it to "sharing your house with ten other families." He speaks in a conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a presentation slide titled "Existing Launch Options Dismal," comparing the current state of rideshare satellite launches with the desired capacity for dedicated launches. The left side of the slide shows a limited capacity of less than 300 satellites per year, while the right side highlights the desired vector capacity of more than 1000 satellites per year. The scene transitions to another slide titled "Lowering Barriers To Space Access," showcasing advancements in 2018 and 2019, including high launch rates and low costs for Vector-R/Vector-H launch vehicles in 2018, and software-defined satellites for Galactic Sky in 2019. The video then shifts to a live event where a man, dressed in a dark blazer and jeans, stands on a stage illuminated by purple lights, presenting to an audience. The stage features a sign that reads "SLUSH," indicating the event's name. The presenter gestures with his hands, engaging with the audience. The scene transitions to a close-up of the presenter, emphasizing his gestures and expressions. The video then shows a wide shot of the stage, capturing the presenter from a distance, with the audience visible in the foreground. The final segment of the video displays a slide titled "Linear Reduction In Scale Exponential Reduction In Costs," illustrating various rockets and their associated costs, ranging from $1.5M for Vector-R/M to $1.5B for Saturn V. The slide emphasizes the technological advancements that enable reducing scale while retaining simplicity and performance. The video concludes with a focus on the presenter, who continues to engage with the audience, highlighting the key points of the presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker enthusiastically describing how they aim to "lower the barriers to space access". He explains their business strategy involves using small launch vehicles and building a "constellation of software defined satellites". According to the male speaker, users will program it "like you would a cellphone with apps." He mentions that reducing the size of a rocket drastically cuts costs and compares their Vector rockets to the rockets that went to the moon, reducing the cost from "a billion and a half dollars to launch" to "one and a half million" for their rockets.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a presentation slide titled "Linear Reduction In Scale Exponential Reduction In Costs," showcasing various rockets with their respective costs, ranging from $1.5M to $1.5B. The scene transitions to a dimly lit stage with purple lighting, where a speaker stands in front of a large screen displaying the "Vector Launch Family" and a list of rockets. The audience is visible in the background, attentively watching the presentation. The speaker, dressed in a dark suit, gestures towards the screen as the lighting shifts to a mix of purple and blue hues, creating a dynamic atmosphere. The presentation then moves to a slide titled "A New Monetization Strategy," comparing traditional and Vector launch strategies, highlighting differences in capital expenditure, scale, and efficiency. The speaker continues to engage the audience, emphasizing the points on the slide. The video concludes with the speaker standing on the stage, with the audience still visible in the background, as the lighting and stage setup remain consistent, maintaining the professional and engaging atmosphere of the presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a "fundamental change" in accessing space and mentions two launch vehicles called "Vector R" and "Vector H," the latter being a tongue-in-cheek reference to a "heavy rocket." He explains that these are small rockets meant to launch microsatellites, addressing that market. He highlights the difference of building these rockets in large numbers, drawing a parallel to automotive technology and stating they are doing the "opposite" of taking rocket technology to cars. He notes the mass production of these rockets, and aims to produce and fly them by hundreds. This, he claims, allows the rockets to be cheaper and creates more profit. He concludes by referencing Henry Ford's Model T as an inspiration.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, illuminated by blue and purple lights, addressing an audience. The stage is adorned with vertical light strips, and a large screen behind him displays the IBM logo. The scene transitions to a slide titled "Making Rockets Like Sausages," comparing "Franchise Rocket Manufacturing" with an image of rockets and "Franchise Food Manufacturing" with a McDonald's restaurant, suggesting a parallel between the two industries. The next slide, "Use Modern Manufacturing," contrasts the production rates of Maserati and SpaceX, showing a significant increase in efficiency from the 1960s to 2015. The video then returns to the stage, where the man continues his presentation, with the screen now displaying "SLUSH" and "SLUSH.BE," indicating the event's name and website. The atmosphere is professional and engaging, with the audience focused on the speaker.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the idea of "making rockets like sausages," suggesting a manufacturing approach where production can be franchised across various locations. He mentions the goal of establishing assembly plants closer to customers, initially in the United States and eventually expanding to places like Europe. The speaker emphasizes that there's no need to reinvent anything new, referring to SpaceX and its Falcon rockets, highlighting their limited production capacity and the reason for reusability to increase flight rates. The speaker has a business-like and informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a man standing on a dimly lit stage, dressed in a dark suit and gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The stage is illuminated by spotlights, and a sign reading "SLUSH" is visible in the background, indicating the event's name. The audience is seated in a darkened auditorium, with some individuals visible in the foreground. The scene transitions to a close-up of the man, who continues to speak and gesture, with purple lights in the background adding to the ambiance. The camera then zooms out to reveal a wider view of the stage, showing multiple screens displaying information and the audience in the background. The man continues his presentation, and the camera captures a close-up of a slide titled "New Transportation Model," comparing the costs and flight frequencies of airplanes and rockets. The slide shows an airplane with 100-400 flights per year at a cost of $1.5-3.0M per flight, and a rocket with 10-20 flights per year at a cost of $60-120M per flight. The video concludes with a wider view of the stage, showing the man continuing his presentation, with the audience visible in the background and the stage illuminated by spotlights and purple lights.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker discusses emulating modern automotive manufacturing techniques to increase launch rates, comparing it to the transition of Maserati in the 60s. He then speaks about the need for a more reliable transportation model for satellites. His tone is informative and somewhat technical.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, illuminated by purple lights, with a sign reading "SLUSH" in the background. He is dressed in a black jacket and jeans, gesturing as he speaks to an audience. The scene transitions to an aerial view of a desert landscape, showcasing a rocket launch site with the text "Vector Block 0.001 Flight - 6 May 2017" displayed. The video then shifts to another rocket launch, this time in a forested area, with the text "B0.002 Flight - Camden Spaceport" visible. The final scene features a rocket on a trailer near the ocean, with the text "First Flights @ Wallops - July 2018" displayed, indicating the location and date of the launch. Throughout the video, the focus is on the rocket launches and the associated locations, highlighting the progression of rocket technology and its testing sites.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing their company's progress in the industry, including purchasing a company and subsequent rapid advancements. He notes a "first flight" in the desert, followed by another flight in Georgia. He says "everybody's got to have a little bit of rocket noise there" right before a brief, loud rocket sound effect is heard. He continues, mentioning a suborbital altitude flight and its recovery from the jungle as proof of their systems' functionality. The speaker outlines a gradual development approach and mentions upcoming first flights to orbit this July from a Virginia flight facility. The sound of speech is in a public setting with light background noise that is consistent and unobtrusive.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, illuminated by purple lights, with a sign reading "SLUSH" in the background. He is dressed in a dark blazer and jeans, gesturing as he speaks to an audience. The scene transitions to a map of the United States titled "Vector Sites," highlighting various locations such as San Jose, CA, Los Angeles, CA, and Cape Canaveral, FL, with labels indicating offices, launch locations, and other facilities. The video then returns to the stage, where the man continues his presentation, now with a backdrop featuring the IBM logo and additional lighting effects. The atmosphere is professional and engaging, with the audience visible in the background. The video concludes with a split-screen view of the "Tucson Rocket Factory," showcasing both the exterior and interior of the facility, emphasizing the modern design and spacious layout. The exterior view highlights the building's sleek architecture and parking lot, while the interior view reveals a well-lit, open-plan office space with large windows and a prominent "VECTOR" sign.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker discussing launching "in a lot of different places in the US," including Alaska, Florida, Wallops, and potentially California, and possibly barges. He mentions the importance of multiple launch sites and the need to transport infrastructure to concrete pads. He then transitions to discussing building a factory in Tucson, Arizona, awarded a contract, which will be "capable of building hundreds of these a year." Groundbreaking is expected soon, aiming for operational status by early 2018-2019. The speaker maintains a conversational and informative tone throughout the description.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a split-screen image showcasing a large rocket engine on the left and a computer screen displaying various graphs and data on the right. The text "Vector's Vision Of Future" is prominently displayed across the center, with "TODAY" on the left side indicating "Hardware Centric $100M Years" and "TOMORROW" on the right side indicating "Software Centric <$1M Months," suggesting a shift from hardware-centric to software-centric operations with a significant reduction in cost and time. The scene transitions to a dimly lit stage with a speaker addressing an audience, illuminated by purple and blue lights, creating a futuristic atmosphere. The speaker, dressed in a dark suit, gestures with his hands while speaking, emphasizing his points. The audience is visible in the background, attentively watching the presentation. The video continues to focus on the speaker, who maintains a confident posture and expressive hand movements, engaging the audience with his presentation. The background remains dark, with purple lights adding to the ambiance, and the speaker's gestures and expressions convey a sense of enthusiasm and expertise. The video maintains a consistent focus on the speaker, highlighting his role in delivering the presentation and the engaging atmosphere of the event.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker describes transforming a hardware-centric industry into a software-centric one, citing software-based innovation and the need to make the space industry more innovative. He mentions launch vehicles and a galactic sky constellation, expressing belief in their potential to achieve this transformation. The speaker concludes with a thank you. Following this, applause indicates audience appreciation.
